title: Monday, 26th September, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

You'll be wanting one of these to hand today -- and maybe keep it close by for the next couple of months

PM

tinhat

11:01 am
PM

But let's get our pic of the day up

PM

PM

Lester Holt

11:02 am
PM

Moderating tonight's Clinton/Trump debate

PM

Tough job

PM

But at least he's had his Ready Brek

11:02 am
PM

You know Holt will get a stream of Twitter stuff as he's moderating the 'debate'

PM

Can that be healthy?

PM

It's a moderated stream, of course

11:03 am
PM

Here's the moderator for the moderator

PM

PM

Adam Sharp

11:03 am
PM

Twitter's head of news and government affairs.

PM

The noise to signal ratio here is what?

PM

Beyond calculation

11:04 am
PM

But what damage at we seeing already Bryce -- here and across London

PM

It's not pretty

BE

Ach. It ain't that bad really. Volume's pretty slim.

11:05 am
BE

FTSE off 1.1% at 6830

PM

Hmm -- worse across Europe, but the CAC, Dax etc always more volatile than us

BE

Yep. We're choosing, largely through a lack of alternatives, to worry about Deutsche Bank and Opec.

11:06 am
BE

Which, in addition to the Fed, are the default worries in times when it's a down day and there's no specific new news.

PM

Well Deutsche is a worry!

PM

Especially if you work there

11:06 am
BE

Yeah, sure .... but ........

BE

BE

Deutsche since 1992, rebased against the Dax.

11:07 am
BE

Put a dollar in a Dax tracker in 1992, you get $7.

BE

Put it into Deutsche and you get 36 cents.

PM

This are shocking stats Bryce

11:08 am
BE

It's been a terrible investment for decades, because the vicious cycle inherent in banks.

BE

As in, they need to issue stock to retain their best people and keep the plates spinning on capital.

BE

As soon as they're fragile they can't raise cash. And that is basically that.

11:10 am
BE

(@Roddy: no, not total return. But the TR graph's not dramatically different.)

BE

So anyway, today's catalyst seems to be Focus magazine speaking to people familiar with Merkel's thinking

PM

Ah, is it now

11:11 am
BE

"unidentified government officials" say no state bailout for Deutsche.

PM

Ms Merkel refusing money

PM

And this has been denied, has it?

11:12 am
BE

Kinda denied. Flashes crossing a few moments ago saying no decisions made.

PM

How could there be a state bail out? Has no one seen what's been happening in Italy and elsewhere?

PM

It's against the rules

11:12 am
PM

How could they possibly bail out Deutsche while refusing the same route to all the peripheral banks.

PM

Actually, on that subject, something has got to happen in Italy soon.

PM

People seem to have forgot the rather toxic problems there

11:13 am
BE

Well, yes. The specific risk with Deutsche that doesn't overhang other banks is of course the DOJ settlement.

PM

Well yes

BE

As in, the DOJ going Dr Evil and demanding $14bn, rather than the €5.5bn provision

11:14 am
BE

But there's a general idea out there that the DOJ's all bluster

BE

SocGen incoming ......

BE

Conduct fines are not designed to cripple a bank: At the risk of stating the obvious, conduct
charges are not designed to induce financial instability, nor will they in our view. In fact, we
think the DoJ has made its move now precisely because the European banks are in a
position to cover the costs. In short, we don’t think the DoJ fine will be the straw that
breaks DB’s back, and Fitch seems to agree (see here). Our analysis below indicates that
even post a $14bn DoJ fine, DB’s CT1 ratio would remain above 9.0% fully loaded. Not
comfortable, but surely above the point of non-viability?

11:15 am
BE

So ......

BE

AT1 coupon skip is possible: The trouble with DB’s AT1s is an awkward Available
Distributable Items (AID) test. We are expecting DB’s FY16 ADI to be a solid €3.4bn (see
page 8 of our recent report), but if DB is forced to take additional provisions in 2016 and
cannot offset this with a capital raise or a transfer of blocked reserves, the ADI could be
depleted. DB could then be (unwillingly) forced to skip the May 2017 (annual) AT1 coupon. Although this is ostensibly priced in (€6% AT1 at 78.4), we would argue that you still don’t want to own the first AT1 that skips a coupon – however unlikely.

PM

( SoS -- ECB has a bail-in regime, introduced post crisis)

11:16 am
BE

Another wee chart, perhaps irrelevant ......

BE

Deutsche CDS going back to pre crisis .....

BE

11:17 am
BE

Sure, elevated, but nowhere near the year highs reached in February.

PM

Lovely chart, but i do wonder how much CDS is actually traded these days -- how indicative prices are

BE

Well indeed. When I pointed this out to Miles Johnston earlier he pointed out that DB CoCos are probably the better indicator of stress, and I don't have that chart to hand.

11:19 am
BE

So anyway, sector down without being meltdown.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 166.40, down 5 (-2.92%), High: 169.60, Low: 165.80, Volume: 21.75m
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 54.22, down 1.76 (-3.14%), High: 55.45, Low: 54.09, Volume: 69.89m
11:19 am
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 178.90, down 3.7 (-2.03%), High: 181.80, Low: 178.40, Volume: 5.27m
BE

There's a Goldman note around this morning, selling Lloyds and Metro

BE

(Which has been a .... um .... surprisingly good market since flotation.)

11:20 am
PM

Metro been extraordinary performer

BE

(I mean, I know there's no free float, but .....)

BE

Here's the cover page from Goldman.

11:21 am
BE

Three months on, what has Brexit changed?

Indicators of UK economic activity have been
volatile since the UK’s vote to leave the EU.
However evidence of a marked decline in activity
is absent at this stage, even though risks clearly
remain, in our view.

BE

Despite this, the monetary policy response has
meant two important changes to the operating
environment for the UK’s banks. (1) The base rate
has fallen by 25 bp and the MPC has heavily
signaled that a further cut (to ~10 bp) is likely
before the turn of the year. (2) In order to ensure
that borrowers feel the benefit of rate reductions,
the BoE has introduced the Term Funding Scheme
(and amended the leverage ratio denominator).

BE

Lower for (even) longer squeezes margins

The mortgage market remains highly competitive;
consequently we expect the full cumulative
impact of 40 bp of rate cuts to feed through to
front-book pricing. In addition, the step-down in
market yields will further pressure margin support
from structural hedges. We do not expect lower
deposit rates to fully offset this impact.

11:22 am
BE

Stress test analysis demonstrates resilience

We run a stress test across UK-exposed banks to
assess the potential impact of a ‘tail risk ‘scenario.
We judge our test to be broadly consistent with a
4.5 pp shock to unemployment. This is an
outcome we view as very unlikely to occur.

Our analysis suggests that Lloyds, along with a
group of the ‘Challengers’ (VM, SHAW, CYBG) are
most exposed to this scenario; however the sector
appears comparatively well capitalized (all banks
are above a 3% leverage ratio and none are
materially below an 8% CET1 ratio).

BE

Lloyds, Metro to Sell; initiate CYBG Neutral

In our view Lloyds’ strategy of maintaining margin
is optimal, but its current valuation (1.0x 16E TBV)
does not fully reflect future margin headwinds; we
downgrade to Sell. We see Metro’s growth plan as
achievable, but see the 3.1x 16E TBV valuation as
stretched. We remain Buy-rated on RBS (given
valuation support) and STAN (restructuring
potential, improving asset quality). We initiate on
CYBG at Neutral: we see the group’s growth, cost
and IRB-driven ROTE improvement as priced-in.

PM

It's Monday, don't Metro Bank have a Conga on Monday's?

11:23 am
PM
BE

Ah, yes. I haven't checked Twitter for my daily Brentian proxy embarrassment.

BE

That's one reason to sell Metro, and a difficult one to argue with.

11:24 am
BE

Goldman's note doesn't touch on the enforced group fun activities though.

PM

Shame

BE

Metro Bank’s shares are up 33% since the close on June 23, and are up 72% since their lowest point following
the referendum outcome. The bank’s shares currently trade at 3.1x 2016E P/TBV and 11.4x 2020E P/E. We see the
group’s ambitious growth plan as achievable and on track and expect it to go from being lossmaking in 2016E,
to generating an ROTE of 20% in 2020E. However, despite this (and a timely transition to the IRB approach for
calculating capital requirements) being incorporated into our estimates and valuation framework, our 12-month
price target implies 26% downside. Consequently we see better value elsewhere in our European Banks
coverage universe and downgrade the shares to Sell from Neutral.

11:25 am
BE

We expect Metro Bank’s 3Q16 results (to be released on October 26) to highlight the group’s continued growth
in both deposits and loans. In addition we expect the rate of the group’s store roll-out to accelerate through the
second half of this year (following only one store opening in the first 6 months of this year). While any
significant slowing of deposit and loan growth would act as a catalyst for our Sell rating, we do not expect this
to occur in the near term. Instead our Sell thesis is based around the shares’ current valuation level and given
their comparatively strong performance over recent months, we would expect a gradual de-rating from current
levels.

BE

We value Metro Bank using the ROTE/COE methodology that we apply across our European banks coverage. We
base our valuation on 2020E returns, since (i) this captures the significant return improvement that we expect
the group to deliver by 2020E and (ii) using 2020E also captures the full impact of the group’s planned transition
to the IRB approach for calculating capital requirements. We assume a COE of 12% (in-line with our estimate for
Virgin Money and CYBG) and also assume a perpetual growth rate of 4%. Our 12-month price target is 2,050p
(from 1,630p), implying 26% downside, vs. 15% upside for our European banks coverage. Consequently we
downgrade the shares to Sell.
We have adjusted estimates, chiefly to reflect a stronger outlook for loan and deposit volume growth. Our 2019E
and 2020E earnings estimates are 5% and 3% below Bloomberg consensus respectively, chiefly due to slightly
lower revenues.

BE

Key risks to our view and price target include better-than-expected deposit and loan growth, lower costs and a
larger-than-anticipated reduction in risk-weighted assets resulting from the group’s planned transition to the IRB
approach for calculating capital requirements.

11:26 am
BE

Sorry about the lumpy formatting.

BE

Wait, what? 3.1 times 2016 tangible NAV?

BE

Why on earth?

11:27 am
BE

Lloyds as well, since we're here.

BE

Lloyds, the UK’s largest mortgage lender, saw a marked decline in new business share in 1H16 to 15% (17% in 2015), which led to a 3% annualized decline in mortgage balances. Importantly, we see two further sources of incremental competition from here: (1) HSBC will continue to strengthen its intermediary distribution as it seeks to deploy significant excess deposits into UK mortgages; (2) the TFS will provide the ‘Challengers’ with a very low-cost funding source. We view Lloyds’ margin maintenance strategy as optimal. Nevertheless, we believe increased competition will have a significant impact on profitability, and downgrade our rating to Sell.

BE

We believe 3Q16 and 4Q16 results will provide further evidence of a continued decline in the size of Lloyds’ mortgage book. In addition, the monthly release of Term Funding Scheme (TFS) usage data will provide important data points on the extent to which ‘Challenger’ banks (among others) are likely to compete in Lloyds’ core product segments.

11:28 am
BE

We lower our EPS estimates by 0%-10% for 2016-18E, mainly to reflect a further base rate cut to 10 bp in November and a continued gradual decline in mortgage balances. Our 12-month ROTE/COE-based price target falls 6% to 50p, implying 13% downside (vs. 15% upside for our European Banks coverage). With the stock trading at 1.0x 2017E P/TBV (vs. our EU Banks coverage at 0.9x) for a 2018 ROTE of 8.3% (vs. European Banks coverage at 10%), Lloyds’ valuation appears challenging, and consequently we downgrade our rating on the shares to Sell from Neutral, as we see better opportunities elsewhere.

BE

And that's enough banks, right? I'm of the opinion that that's enough banks.

PM

Yes, but thanks for all that

11:28 am
undefined
PM

Pearson not looking so clever

PM

Not very clever at all

11:29 am
Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 735.83, down 22.17 (-2.93%), High: 756.00, Low: 729.50, Volume: 1.19m
PM

This went as high as 960p over the summer

PM

It as above 800p two weeks ago

11:30 am
BE

I know we go on about Pearson a lot, buy I find this theme dead interesting.

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

Everyone in the sector's warned on this, but they're all reading it in different ways.

11:31 am
PM

hmm

BE

It might be that folk can download textbooks when needed, rather than buying them all at the start of term, so it's just delayed sales.

BE

Or it might be the fact that book rentals and eBay and .... well, Torrenting, basically .... is destroying the primary market.

11:32 am
BE

We don't know. The companies don't seem to know.

BE

On Friday we had the CEO of Houghton Mifflin exit.

BE

And guide for results at the lower end of its previous warning.

11:34 am
PM

This was Linda Zecher,

PM

PM

We're assuming John Fallon is safe at Pearson tho, right?

11:35 am
PM

I mean, given that everyone else in the sector seems to have come out with some warning, and Pearson hasn't...

PM

That means things are ok, right?

PM

And even if things are not 100 per cent ok, then John can just come out with another restructuring.

11:36 am
PM

Cos he knows what he's doing there

PM

Restructuring

BE

Well, to be frank, what can Mr Fallon do? The education market's under structural attack and the previous disposals -- FTSE, Mergermarket ...... us -- have removed the diversity of revenue that damped the impact.

11:36 am
PM

hehe

BE

The FT Group was, for quite some time, the fastest growing bit of Pearson I think.

BE

Anyway, here's Liberum to say "sell Pearson"

11:37 am
BE

As Liberum says about three times each day.

BE

The CEO of Houghton Mifflin stepped down on Friday after five years with the company also pointing to its FY results now being at the lower end of its (previously reduced) guidance. Houghton Mifflin is one of the three major US K-12 (schools) publishers and, while our main concerns over Pearson relate to the latter’s US Higher Education business, the news is another reminder of the difficulties of the US education publishing market. Reiterate as top Sell.

BE

US K-12 publisher Houghton Mifflin’s shares fell 11% on Friday after the company’s long-standing CEO, Linda Zecher, stepped down. At the same time, the company announced that FY'16E billings will be “will be at or near the low end of the Company’s revised guidance of $1,525 million to $1,595 million for 2016.”, guidance which itself had been lowered at the Q2 results in August, where the company blamed lower than expected new adoptions and lower than expected growth in an acquired business. Along with Pearson, Houghton Mifflin is one of the three major US K-12 education publishers.

11:37 am
BE

Houghton did not provide any more information as to why it was guiding to the lower end of guidance: it may be more market-related (e.g. the new adoption market is softer than expected) or more firm-specific (the EdTech business has suffered further problems) but, whatever the reason, it does not suggest a more positive outlook for the US K-12 education publishing arena, which has implications for Pearson although it is not a major divisional for the Group (we estimate K-12 publishing is just over 2% of profits for Pearson).

BE

Our biggest concern with Pearson is in its US Higher Education business (estimated 45% of group profits) and not its K-12 business. Nevertheless, the news from Houghton Mifflin, together with negative comments on the US Higher Education publishing trends from peer J Wiley (NR) and college bookstore business Barnes and Noble Education (NR) suggest the education publishing market is facing significant headwinds that appear to be gaining momentum. Pearson is extremely H2 weighted (

100% of profits for FY'16E) and we believe both it will both deliver another profit warning and that its problems are primarily structural in nature.

BE

Our biggest concern with Pearson is in its US Higher Education business (estimated 45% of group profits) and not its K-12 business. Nevertheless, the news from Houghton Mifflin, together with negative comments on the US Higher Education publishing trends from peer J Wiley (NR) and college bookstore business Barnes and Noble Education (NR) suggest the education publishing market is facing significant headwinds that appear to be gaining momentum. Pearson is extremely H2 weighted (greater than 100% of profits for FY'16E) and we believe both it will both deliver another profit warning and that its problems are primarily structural in nature.

11:39 am
BE

(@SoS: I think I have about £75 in the Pearson scheme, so am looking forward to a pretty sweet retirement.)

PM

(SoS -- we've switched to a new provider. But those on defined benefit have been closed out.)

undefined
11:39 am
BE

So leading the fallers we have ............

InterContinental Hotels Group PLC (IHG:LSE): Last: 3,151, down 134 (-4.08%), High: 3,233, Low: 3,135, Volume: 449.45k
BE

.......... which is on a Morgan Stanley downgrade to underweight.

11:40 am
PM

What's this on?

BE

Largely on valuation, but also on a US market downturn

PM

US?

11:41 am
PM

Don't tell me it's AirBnB

BE

Not specifically, though I'm sure it's mentioned somewhere in the 41 pages.

BE

Mostly it's just the worry that the US lodging market for some time has been too much supply coming on tap, the main chains having overbuilt over the past decade.

11:42 am
BE

Against that backdrop the extra supply from AirBnB does have an incremental drag

BE

(I'm typing quite jargonny today. Apologies for that.)

PM

Meanwhile, AirBnB raising fresh cash at a $30bn valuation last week -- compared with, what, $8bn market cap for InterCont?

11:43 am
PM

But do carry on with MOST

BE

Well, we can argue for some time about whether $30bn is the right valuation to use based on the new money coming in

BE

But instead, here's the AirBnB charts ......

11:44 am
BE

BE

And ...............

BE

11:45 am
BE

Sorry they're a tad blurry.

BE

Back to the top.

BE

HG has outperformed peers YTD (in USD) and now trades in
line despite its weaker RevPAR / system growth. Meanwhile,
multiple signals are flashing that the US hotel cycle is peaking.
We cut RevPAR forecasts, partly offset by an assumed $500m
buyback, but IHG looks fully valued so we move UW.

11:45 am
BE

IHG has enjoyed a strong re-rating... IHG shares are up +10% YTD in USD terms
vs US peers MAR+4% / CHH -7%. Its NTM P/E multiple has re-rated from a 12%
discount to a 5% premium (18.5x), and its FY17e EV/EBITDA of 12x is top-end. IHG
has an attractive and resilient business model, with an attractive 5.6% FCF yield,
and M&A is a theme, but it has historically traded at a discount to peers, partly
as its RevPAR and net system growth have underperformed.
... meanwhile there are multiple red flags over the US hotel cycle ... US RevPAR
growth has been slowing for some time (2014 8.3%, 2015 6.4%, YTD 2.7%), and
we think it will weaken further given declining occupancy, anaemic rate growth,
accelerating supply growth, one-fifth of submarkets in RevPAR decline,
'compression nights' analysis suggesting Airbnb now having an impact, and
independent hotels outperforming brands. If we match these occupancy /
RevPAR trends to the last two cycles, IHG shares are holding up much better.

BE

... so we reduce forecasts with lower RevPAR offsetting another $500m
buyback ... We now see +1.5% RevPAR growth in 2017 (+2% prior) and -1% in
2018 (+2%), which more than offsets the $500m (5%) buyback we assume in
2017, given IHG will end 2016 with 2.2x ND/EBITDA versus its 2.0-2.5x target.
... and on balance we downgrade to Underweight. IHG is a quality operator, but
when RevPAR turns, all hotel stocks de-rate sharply, which in the last downturn
was to 8-9x EBITDA (vs. IHG currently on 12x 2017e). M&A speculation may
continue to provide support, but we think that IHG sees itself as more of a buyer
than a seller, and it no longer owns 'trophy' assets. We trim our PT from £33 to
£31 – admittedly not much downside, but the risk-reward ratio looks relatively
unattractive given 40% implied downside to our £20 bear case (-7% RevPAR, 9x
EBITDA), and we think the 25 October Q3 update will look weak.

PM

Back to Airbnb -- setting the valuation aside -- I'm not sure how good it actually is.

11:46 am
PM

In the big cities, it's full of scammers.

PM

The site is actually quite limited on the information it provides about the accommodation

PM

The search is difficult to use

11:47 am
PM

And those renting rooms are putting the prices up, sharply -- cos they've learnt the real costs of renting your flat out to temporary occupants

PM

As a user, you can be lucky or unlucky.

BE

Oh, I dunno. I've used AirBnB on occasion, and liked it, but it's for specific uses.

11:48 am
BE

If I need a check-in at midnight I'm going to a Holiday Inn.

PM

(Those penetration figures above look suspect to me. 17% in 2016? I don't think so -- but i havent read the full report.)

BE

AirBnB is clearly exceptionally popular though so I put it in that category of "things other people use more than I'd want to, so I can't really claim to understand."

11:49 am
BE

As to the silly valuation, it's silly. I've not much to add to that observation.

undefined
BE

What about N Brown? We don't mention that much on here.

11:51 am
N Brown Group PLC (BWNG:LSE): Last: 184.90, down 2.4 (-1.28%), High: 185.40, Low: 181.10, Volume: 170.61k
BE

Apart from to note that it's a hilariously expensive unsecured lending book pretending to be a retailer.

BE

HSBC has some concern.

11:52 am
BE

Unscheduled update delivers positive news flow on FCA authorisation...: JD Williams, the key N Brown operating company, has been granted full Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) authorisation. This announcement is a strategic positive for the group in that it allows N Brown to continue trading without any significant caveats or conditions. It does not, however, impact our short-to-medium-term earnings expectations, which were premised on the authorisation being granted from the outset.

BE

... but negatives on implementation of IT systems and exceptional costs: The necessary transformation plan required to build a scalable model with long-term potential, originally announced in 2014, has met with higher-than-expected costs/ reduced benefits, negatively impacting short-to-medium-term earnings. However, we see an increasing likelihood that the planned increase in investment is a significant and permanent step change in N Brown's ongoing investment requirement. The 'Fit 4 Future' systems programme will see the group launch its new US platform in September, slightly later than planned. However, the unforeseen complexity and cost of completing this platform mean the group will not now look at rebuilding its UK platform until next year. This will incur increased investment and delay the implementation of necessary systems, probably on a multi-year basis. Although management 'anticipates' being able to provide greater detail at the interim results, the net conclusion is that the transformation plan is not on track (as was previously communicated), and the cost and time to completion are increasing again.

BE

Cut TP to 205p from 230p; downgrade rating to Hold from Buy: In the absence of new guidance on capex, we make no changes to our FY17-19 estimates ahead of the interim results in October. For reference we forecast H1 sales flat at GBP428m and PBT -9% to GBP32m. Our FY17-19 estimates are broadly in line with consensus expectations. We cut our target price to 205p from 230p driven by a 10% increase in the company-specific beta to 1.1 to reflect increased downside risk to earnings, in our view. N Brown trades on a CY17e PE of 8.5x, a c22% discount to the sector. Given continued negative earnings momentum we see limited catalysts for this discount to narrow in the short term. Next potential catalyst: Interim results on 11 October.

11:53 am
BE

So that's that noted.

undefined
BE

@erlkin mentions the Twitter story from Friday.

11:54 am
BE

CNBC says Twitter's officially for sale and in the early stage of listening to offers, in a very weirdly phrased story.

BE

Everyone else matched it soon after.

BE

The weirdest part of it was the list of buyers, which alongside the expected names included Salesforce.

11:56 am
BE

What might an enterprise cloud computing CRM thing want with Twitter?

PM

To distract from the core product?

PM

Whenever i have to use salesforce here, i have to set aside an hour for the wasted clicking around to find what I want, and then having to email someone for help when i fail to do so.

11:57 am
PM

Or maybe that's just the way we have it set up here

PM

Loath using it

BE

I'm playing the AirBnB card here again. I don't understand Salesforce, or claim to, but it certainly seems to make money.

11:57 am
BE

Enough to host ludicrous parties in Davos, for one thing.

BE

Anyway, BMO tries to make sense of this.

BE

We think salesforce.com could leverage Twitter in three ways. First, Twitter could be
used to enhance a search process to target sales prospects, although we think the
profile info provided by Twitter is limited and does not add nearly as much value as
LinkedIn profiles. Second, Twitter has a product called Gnip, which helps companies
better understand the performance of their content, as well as providing insights
about their audiences. We think Gnip can be used in salesforce.com’s Marketing and
Service Cloud, but we believe Gnip is a small portion of Twitter's revenue, likely less
than 5%. Lastly, we think Twitter’s large database and real-time news functionality
can be leveraged in salesforce.com’s new AI initiative, Einstein.

11:58 am
BE

Then concludes that, actually, it doesn't make sense.

BE

However, we disagree with the potential strategic rationale for acquiring Twitter
and believe it would be a suboptimal use of capital. We think Twitter's primary
value is as a social platform, not for business use, and we do not think it fits well
in salesforce.com’s enterprise software platform relative to the capital required to
complete a deal. Moreover, if salesforce.com were to make a bid for Twitter, we
would wonder if the deal would be a reflection of growth trends in salesforce.com's
existing business.

BE

We consider salesforce.com's current valuation attractive at 30.4x EV/FY2018E
FCF, compared with the average one- and two-year multiples of 32.5x and 35.4x,
respectively. However, we advise caution in the near term until more is known about
the potential outcome with Twitter.

11:59 am
BE

And if you want a broader waffle about Twitter's strategic value (a case we can argue against endlessly with application of anecdote, and I'm sure the ROTR can too) .... Here's JMP Securities.

BE

We have always thought of Twitter as a strategic asset given it is the real-time web platform
with proprietary and differentiated content across its 313 million MAUs and that it would make sense for Twitter to be a part of a larger organization like Google, potentially
Facebook (FB, MO, $165 PT), and others given its recent engagement and monetization
challenges, notwithstanding regulatory risks. In this note, we highlight what we believe
would be a fair valuation range in the event of an acquisition, which we believe would be
~$22-$28 per share. This implies an enterprise value of $13.5 billion to ~$18 billion and
is based on a 2017E EBITDA multiple range of 16.5x to ~22x (on 2018 EBITDA, this
implies ~15x to ~19x). We believe this valuation range takes into account the strategic
value of Twitter offset by the weakening engagement and monetization trends across
its business. On the strategic side, as part of a larger organization, we believe Twitter
would benefit from improved distribution and monetization opportunities. Twitter shares
are up ~20% on the news (vs. a slightly down S&P 500), although given the operational
challenges and the uncertainty of any potential acquisition, we believe that the risk/
reward on shares of Twitter is balanced until we can see consistent (and meaningful)
MAU growth and stabilizing owned and operating advertising revenue growth and that shares are fairly valued at current levels. For 2016E, we project revenue of $2.5 billion (+15% Y/Y), EBITDA of $688 million (+23% Y/Y, 27.0% margin on gross revenue) and PF EPS of $0.48.

BE

Our valuation range for Twitter shares: $22-28 per share. In an acquisition, we
believe Twitter shares could be worth $22 - $28 per share, implying a total enterprise
value of $13.5 billion to ~$18 billion. We arrive at this based on what we believe would
be a strategic EBITDA multiple range of 16.5x to ~22x on our 2017E projections (using
our 2018E projections, our EBITDA multiples are ~15x to ~19x). We believe this range
accounts for the strategic benefits of Twitter offset by the current operational challenges
around engagement, monetization, and profitability. On profitability, while we value
Twitter on an EBITDA basis, we note that 100%+ of Twitter’s EBITDA is from non-cash
operating metrics- Depreciation & Amortization and Stock Based Compensation- given
operating income is negative and we do not project positive operating income in the
foreseeable future.

Also worth noting the ludicrous US takeover code that means none of the companies need to respond.

BE

Preliminary Discussions
Many acquisition transactions in the US commence with preliminary negotiations and/or
discussions between the acquirer and the target company. As a general matter, a target
company and an acquirer are not under any obligation to disclose preliminary
discussions, even if requested to confirm or deny discussions by investors, the press or
the New York Stock Exchange. If, however, the acquirer or the target company chooses
to confirm or deny rumours, it must do so accurately. It is also very common for
preliminary discussions to take place pursuant to a negotiated confidentiality agreement.
There is no restriction on the ability of a target company to provide information to a
potential acquirer if the board of directors of the target company believes it is appropriate
to do so.
